Authors:
Andre Rodrigues, Michel RZ Passarini, Milene Ferro, Nilson
S Nagamoto, Luiz C Forti, Mauricio Bacci, Lara Duraes Sette, Fernando C
Pagnocca
Title: Fungal communities in nest soils of leaf-cutting ants
Keywords:
Attini, microfungi, community, isolation, ITS sequencing,
cloning
Abstract:
Leaf-cutting ants modify the physical and chemical
properties of the soil adjacent to their nests. Here, we examined
whether such an ant-altered environment impacts the belowground fungal
communities. Fungal diversity and community structure of nest soils of
Atta sexdens rubropilosa and Atta bisphaerica, two widespread
leaf-cutting ants in Brazil, were determined and compared with non-nest
soils. Culture-dependent methods revealed similar species richness in
nest and non-nest soils; but community composition differed between both
types of soils. Penicillium janthinellum and Trichoderma spirale were
the most prevalent fungi found in nest and non-nest soils, respectively.
In contrast to cultivation methods, analyses of ITS rDNA libraries
indicated that richness of operational taxonomic units (OTUs)
significantly differed between nest and non-nest soils. FastUnifrac
analyses based on ITS sequences further revealed clear distinction in
the community structure between nest and non-nest soils. Plectania
milleri and an uncultured Clavariaceae fungus were the most prevalent
OTUs in nest and non-nest soils, respectively. FastUnifrac analyses also
revealed that fungal community structure of nest soils markedly differed
between ant species. Our findings suggest that leaf-cutting ants affect
fungal communities in the soil adjacent to their nests.
